Sheet-Based Calculator

Introduction
The sheet-based calculator is a program which does mathematical expression calculations in a word-processing-like environment. It performs simple operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division etc. It also allows users to assign value to a variable. It also able to calculate trigonometric function such as cos, sin, tan, log etc.

Mathematical Operators Supported
Open Bracket (
Close Bracket )
Addition +
Subtraction -
Multiplication *
Division /
Power ^
Scientific Notation EXP

Functions Supported
Sine sin
Cosine cos
Tangent tan
Arc sine arcsin
Arc cosine arccos
Arc tangent arctan
Exponential ex
Logarithm log
Natural logarithm ln

Evaluating Mathematical Expressions
1) Type in the mathematical expression.
2) Highlight the expression.
3) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
1 + 1 <-- highlight both and press evaluate
2 + 2 <-- highlight both and press evaluate
= 2.0 <-- answers will appear in the following lines
= 4.0
Example 2:
1 + 1
2 + 2 <-- cursor is in here, press evaluate
= 4.0 <-- calculator will only evaluate the current line
Using variables
1) Use the [=] sign to assign values to variables
Example
A = 1 <-- press evaluate
= 1.0
2) Simply refer to the variables in any expression and evaluate as before.
Example
A + 2
= 3.0

Defining Functions
1) Type in a function name followed by (x).
2) Type in "=" and define the function
3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
f(x) = 3*x + 6 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 3*x+6 <-- answers will appear in the following lines

Calling Functions
1) The function must have been defined first. Once that is done, proceed with step 2.
2) Type in a function name followed by (x).
3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
f(x) <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 3*x+6 <-- answers will appear in the following lines

Solving Functions
1) The function must have been defined first. Once that is done, proceed with step 2.
2) Type in a function name followed by brackets with a number you wish to replace x with.
3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
f(2) <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 12.0 <-- answers will appear in the following lines

Changing settings
Certain settings such as the precise number of decimal places calculations should be calculated in (precision), and the number of digits before answers are displayed in significant figures (sdigits) can be changed by the user. Type in the appropriate commands into the sheet to change them. Here are the steps to do so:

1) Type in precision followed by an "=", enter the number of decimal places you wish to calculate in
2) Type in sdigits followed by an "=", enter the number of digits you wish to see before answers get converted to significant figure notation
3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
sdigits = 10 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
60+60 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 120.0 <-- answers will appear in the following lines
Example 2:
sdigits = 2 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
60+60 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 1.2e2 <-- answers will appear in the following lines
